awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021:  Uncovering the Mechanisms of Convergent Tooth Loss in Frogs
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Teeth are present in most living vertebrates. However, complete tooth loss has evolved in a few groups of fishes, reptiles, and mammals. Though the arrangement and condition of amphibian teeth has been poorly studied, recent work shows that frogs have lost teeth more than 20 times. The mechanisms underlying tooth loss in frogs are unknown, but examining possible developmental, genetic, and environmental factors will provide insight to how predictable and repeatable this process is from an evolutionary point of view. The aim of this project is to determine if there is a core set of genes required for tooth development, and to test if the environment (temperature) can affect tooth development. The fellowship will facilitate mentorship training by fostering research opportunities for undergraduate students. Digital anatomy resources will be created for middle school teachers and students to provide real examples of evolution through natural selection using museum specimens. 

The proliferation of teeth in fishes and amniotes is mediated by at least four major signaling pathways, and the loss of different signals arrests dental development and underlies tooth loss in birds, turtles, and some mammals. With phylogenetically widespread tooth loss and separate evolutionary losses on upper and lower jaws, frogs offer an unparalleled opportunity for investigating the mechanisms of repeated trait loss. The fellow will use immunohistochemistry, in situ hybridization, and transcriptomics to characterize dental development in amphibians and assess if different signals arrest tooth development among species that have independently lost teeth. Within tetrapods, enamel and dentin are found only in teeth, and these tissues are formed by proteins encoded by tooth-specific, non-pleiotropic genes. Comparative genomics will be used to identify if enamel and dentin genes have become non-functional in toothless frogs via novel inactivating mutations. Environmental factors may impact dental anatomy by altering developmental rate. An experimental approach will be used to test if one such factor, temperature, impacts the anatomy and expression patterns of frog dentition. Creation of digital resources for anatomy education and PI participation in mentoring undergraduate students and outreach will broaden the impact of the project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Whether organisms independently generate similar traits via similar underlying mechanisms is a fundamental question because the predictability and repeatability of evolutionary processes remain unknown. Teeth have been lost several times during the evolution of vertebrates, resulting in toothlessness, but is most widespread in frogs with over 20 independent losses. Investigations in toothless fishes, reptiles, and mammals have found that the tooth development program is not completely lost. These species maintain early molecular signaling and can develop transient tooth bud rudiments prior to the termination of the tooth development program that is disrupted via multiple pathways (loss of expression for different genes). Studies that investigate tooth loss in frogs are lacking.

 I characterized the developmental-genetic basis of amphibian tooth formation and evaluated the mechanisms of convergent tooth loss in frogs by generating RNA probes for 22 genes with known vital roles in the early development of teeth. A developmental series of five toothed frog species and four toothless species were obtained for histological sectioning, anatomical investigation, and gene expression analyses. The gene expression data collected during this project demonstrates that the core gene regulatory network that controls tooth development is highly conserved across all major vertebrate groups, providing the first data for toothed amphibians. Unexpectedly, I found little anatomical or molecular evidence that the tooth development program initiates in the upper jaws of any toothless frog species investigated. These results suggest that the underlying developmental mechanism resulting in toothlessness in frogs is distinct from the patterns identified in other toothless vertebrates. Frogs may be unique in this respect because of the dramatic decoupling that has occurred between the timing of primary mouth (stomodeum) formation and the initiation of tooth development, enabling the dental program to be completely lost in some species. In other vertebrates, these two developmental processes co-occur or occur successively early in embryonic development, while in frogs the primary mouth forms early in embryonic development but tooth development does not initiate until metamorphosis (following the tadpole phase). Future research directions will investigate the expression of key transcription factors and signaling molecules in the mouth of frogs across all stages of development, including embryos, tadpoles, and metamorphosed frogs.

 During the award period, I mentored seven undergraduate students at Harvard University, University of Florida, and University of Dayton, during which they gained experience in analyzing 3D data generated from computed tomography scanning, processing vertebrate tissues using histology techniques to study and image microanatomy, using molecular biology tools to visualize gene expression spatial patterns across species, and local fieldwork. This project also supported several public events and outdoor nature walks at the Florida Museum of Natural History to inspire the next generation of scientists and highlight the importance of biodiversity, including two Frog Night Walk events attended by over 100 community members. Lastly, I generated digital anatomy resources to support and extend an educational curriculum focused on  the evolution of form and function in frogs, and these CT scan resources are now freely available for research, education, and outreach.


Last Modified: 01/31/2024
Modified by: Daniel J Paluh
